DIV1.P: A New Test OF THE Sence of the Nation: BEING A Modest Comparison BETWEEN THE ADDRESSES TO THE Late King JAMES, And THOSE to Her Present Majesty.
In Order to Observe, How far The Sence of the Nation may be judg'd of by either of them.
LONDON, Printed in the Year 1710.

DIV1.HEAD: A New Test OF THE SENCE OF THE NATION.
DIV1.P:
THERE are now so many Ways contriv'd to byass the Judgment of the People, and the People themselves have taken up so many New Ways to express them∣selves, that we are oblig'd to take New Ways also, to understand them by. Nothing is more cer∣tain, than that the Methods of Understanding Things must vary as the Methods of Expressing
them vary, or else the Actions of Men will soon come to speak a Language not at all to be un∣derstood, and the Voice of Things will have as much Confusion as the Voices of Men had of Old at the Building of Babel.

Among the great Variety there is to be found in the World of this Kind, nothing seems more remarkable, than the frequent Alterations made in the Meanings of the same Things, whether spoken or done in these few late Years; by which it is grown preposterous to expect, that Men shou'd be suppos'd to mean the same Thing to Day, that they meant yesterday by the same Words.

This might be illustrated by many Examples, but by nothing more plainly than by the various Use, Intent, Meaning and Design of SWEARING; especially that of Taking or Refusing Oaths to Governments, Allegiance to, and Abjuration of Princes, and the like.

Here Men stand off, and refuse to take Oaths to the last Minute, and then with the utmost Re∣luctance, to save a Place, Benefit, or Preferment, they take this Oath, and yet at the same Time, swear that they do it Heartily, Willingly and Truly.

In another Case, Men abjure Foreign Preten∣ders, “”Declaring, Testifying, Professing and Acknowledging (Vide the Abjuration) that they do believe in their Conscience, that the Pre∣tended Prince of Wales, or King James III. so calling himself, hath not any Claim, or Title to the Crown of this Realm, &c.

And at the same Time, these Gentlemen in their open Profession, acknowledge the said Pretender, Drink his Health upon their Knees, Pray Cap in Hand, for his Restitution, and Act openly for his Interest; of which, the Author humbly prays, the swearing Jacobites not to put
him to the Necessity of bringing numerous Ex∣amples, for Fear of a Black List, they wou'd not be glad to see come abroad in the World.

And yet all these Contradictions are easie to be reconcil'd, and the Honesty and Integrity of the Parties may be clearly defended, and this is the Work of the present Undertaking, per∣haps, you may think it difficult, but you may be of another Opinion when you have duly con∣sider'd the Particulars.

There is a Thing call'd The Sence of the Na∣tion; by which, all Things of this Kind are deter∣min'd and understood; and this prevails not against the Literal Meaning of Words only, but against the plain and visible Construction of Mens Actions, and is now become the only true Rule to judge by. Custom has by the Law of Nations, obtain'd a very great Authority all over the World, having in all Ages, been the only Judge of Propriety, the Guide of Languages, the Allow'd Authority for Speech, and having given the true Legitimacy to Words. From hence, It is a most necessary Conse∣quence as well as a certain Truth, that Custom is the great Arbiter of Meaning in Speech: Nor can we give any greater Reason, nor in many Cases, any other Reason, for the Extensiveness of Words, than the Custom and Usage of the Country, that is in Eng∣lish, The Sence of the Nation. No Man can say, why a Spade is call'd a Spade, or a Tree a Tree; why Whore signifies a Leud Woman; why a weak-headed Man is call'd a Fool; why a Man that robs another is call'd a Thief: But that it is the Custom of the Place, that such Words shall be so understood, or to speak more plainly, This is the Sence of the Nation.

The same Authority is given for several Words signifying the same Thing, or several Things being
signify'd by the same Word, frequent Instances of which are to be given in our Language, and all are legitimated by Custom as the Sense of the Nation.

By this Authority of Custom a High-Church-Man and a Mad-Man, a Tory and a Thief, a Whig and a Presbyterian are all become synonimous to one ano∣ther; tho' if we take the People and examine them apart, they pretend quite other Things; but it must be so understood, for 'Tis the Sence of the Nation.

But what shall we say to a new Tyranny of Custom, which is now invading us with Exotick Significations of Words, such as were never heard of here before: By which, for Example, a Sacheverellite and a Jaco∣bite, Mad-Juror and a Non-Juror, a High-Flyer and a French-Panist are become synonimous, and signi∣fy the same Thing; nor are the Etimologies or Vulgar Acceptations of the Words to be alter'd, or their Agreement to be interrupted by the Casual Intervention of Taking or Refusing Oaths, Abjura∣tions, Associations, or any such Trifles upon any Account whatsoever, The Reason is plain, for such is the Sence of the Nation.

All this is brought to pass, by the Wonderful Assistance, and Irresistable Force of CUSTOM, which, by her absolute Authority in the Kingdom of Speech, has full Power to cause what Construc∣tion she pleases to be put upon Words, and to cause them to be understood as best may serve to her Royal Ends and Purposes;—making those Constructions become The Sence of the Nation.

Q.L: Custom, that all the World to Slav'ry brings
That Dull Excuse for doing filly Things.

DIV1.P:
We are next to prove, The Great Usefulness and Convenience of this to Mankind, and consequently,
the Reasonableness, and indeed, Necessity of Sub∣mitting to this Government of Custom; as also, that in all Ages, and in all Nations, she has exercis'd this Authority, and that, therefore, having Prescription to plead for it, she is entitul'd by her immemorial self to an indeseizible Title to it, and may indeed her∣self be call'd The Sence of the Nation.

And first, to the Usefulness of it,—in which it appears like the Copernican System of Philosophy, which, tho' it admits of many Doubts, and has some Difficulties in it, which can allow no Demon∣stration, yet is receiv'd, because by that we can the better solve other Phenomena in Nature, which were perfectly unaccountable, and indeed, inconceivable before: So in this Case, tho' there may be some Objections perhaps, unanswerable a∣gainst this Tyranny of Custom, and some Diffi∣culties in our Subjection to it, which seem absurd, and admit of no Demonstration, yet we receive it as a Thing, by which, we can better solve some strange and wonderful Phaenomena in the Conduct of Mankind, which can no otherwise be accounted for, but by their being The Sence of the Nation.

By this Glorious System, a Man may sail North and South at the same Time in the great Ocean of Politicks; two Men may turn Back to Back in the great Road of Allegiance, and One Travel, that is, Swear, one Way, One another; and marching on strait forward meet at the same Point of Truth and Sincerity. For Example, A Man may swear to the Man he fights against, and fight for the Man he swears against: And all this only by Custom stepping in, and legitimating the Word SWEARING, and JESTING, to mean the same Thing in The Sence of the Nation.

Nor is this a Novelty, or started to gratify a Party, No, no, Gentlemen; I will not do the Jacobites
so much Wrong. However necessary it may, at this Time, be to their Cause, and therefore, very happily made Use of by the Fathers of their Flock; but the Thing has ever been the Custom, of such Kind of People as they are compos'd of, and especially among its, and is, therefore, to be taken here as the Sence of the Nation.

Nor shall I need to be sent back to the Hea∣then Ages of the World, whether Grecian or Roman, in which, tho' the like Authority of Custom had in∣troduc'd the like Practice, yet Generous Principles had almost prevailed to explode her Authority; since it has been observ'd, to revive with the In∣troduction of Christianity, and to obtain more among the Christian Part of the World, than ever it did among the Heathen, and has almost in all Places among them, been the Sence of the Nation.

I need not go to Sacred Writ for the Perjury, or worse, of Jacob to Esau; Breach of Honour in David to the Posterity of Jonathan, and the like; since they have Exceptious in them, which, per∣haps, we cannot so well discant upon in this Place.

I need not dwell upon the Mahometans making a Jest of Keeping Faith with Christians; since we find Christians making the same Jest of Keeping Oaths to to those they call Hereticks and Phanaticks, and that in Rome, France, Italy, and England; it has been the Sence of the Nation.

What need I examine the JEST which Princes have made in the World, of their Swearing to Treaties and Capitulations. The Oaths, Anglice, JESTS of Renunciations of Right and Disclaim∣ing Successions.—The BANTER of Oaths call'd Coronation-Oaths to Subjects, and the like, these are so Subjects, and the like, these are so flagrant they need no Repetition and that they signify nothing, has long been allow'd in France and Elsewhere, to be the Sence of the Nation.

Nor need I go far, to shew you the general Oaths taken by conquer'd Cities and Provinces, to the respective Conquerors Alternately as they subdu'd them. Nor the JESTING, I mean, Swearing of Nations to Princes, whom they think fit afterwards Nationally to Resist, and Depose; since their NON-SIGNIFICATION has on all Oc∣casions appear'd to be the Sence of the Nation.

After all these will you any longer question, that the Swearing, Fore-Swearing, or Back-Swearing; i. e. Abjuring of Parties, can be any more than JESTING; that it can be taken for any other by the Princes to whom, or meant for any other with the Parties by whom they are taken; and that their being taken for a Jest, is now become the Sence of the Nation.

What is that we call CUSTOM, but the Sence of the Nation. Or, The common Acceptat on, in which, such, and such Things are generally re∣ceived; and by which, the Signification, or Non-Signification of what is said, or done, is under∣stood in General.

Let's begin with what we call common Conver∣sation, Here CUSTOM, which I thus call the Sence of the Nation, has commanded that we should understand SWEARING to be really no less than JESTING, and when a Man wishes God may Damn him, or stop his Vitals; when he Curses his Blood, and swears By his Maker, or Redeemer; it is ex∣pected, in good Manners, you should understand him to mean Nothing at all, and 'tis plain, he is so understood in the Sence of the Nation.

God forbid, we shou'd be so barbarous and in∣humane, to take Men Literally when they swear, or to charge them with Meaning when they blas∣pheme God, damn themselves, and swear solemnly to what they say; this wou'd be the unreasonablest
Thing in the World, and you must then charge them with Perjury a Thousand Times a Day. The Case is plain, you must refer to the great Law of Custom, which is The Sence of the Nation.

This Custom governs Kingdoms as well as Men, and directs you to take all the Imprecations and Execrations of the Common Conversation of Men to signify nothing at all; as Froth upon your Drink, which proceeds from its Strength, but when you skim it off, the pure Liquor comes after; so this Swearing is nothing but a certain Froth or Foam of the Mouth proceeding from the Heat of the Passions, which Men throw by and take for no∣thing, and Skimming it off from Speech, the true Genuine Sence of the Man comes after it: And thus it is generally taken in the Sence of the Nation.

From hence it follows, That a Man shall swear a Thousand Street-Oaths in an Hour, to the Truth of a Thing which he knows nothing of, or to do some∣thing he never intends, or that he did something he never thought of, and yet remain a Man of Ho∣nour; if you bring him upon his Oath in a Court of Justice, or make him a Witness between Man and Man, you may depend upon his Evidence to be Punctual and True, and he scorns to for∣swear himself: Nay, he shall pass for a good Wit∣ness, notwithstanding his daily Perjury, in the Sence of the Nation.

The Reason is plain, Custom has preserv'd some Veneration to a Formal Oath in Bearing Witness, but The Sence of the Nation has long since taken away all Signification from the most violent Oaths in the World in common Speech, as Things that neither are intended, or shou'd be understood to have any Kind of Meaning at all in them. H—is an Eminent Justice of Peace, he punishes Drunkenness, Whoring and Swearing impartially, as the Law directs, and when a Man is brought
before him for these Crimes, he decently ex∣horts him to forbear; but he swears and blas∣phemes in the very Act of Executing the Law upon them, and damns himself upon the very Bench. The Case is plain, It is all without any Signification, nay, it is not to be call'd Speech, but a certain Excrement of the Passions which breaks out at the Mouth; it has a kind of Sound, indeed, like Words, but it is hardly known by the Parties themselves; it has no Communica∣tion with the Thoughts, and cannot be under∣stood to have any Meaning at all; like the Igni fatui in the Air, which have an Appearance of Fire, and give a kind of Light, or rather, a shining Reflection of Light, but have no Heat, and are esteem'd as a meer Vapour, without any Signification.

We might enter into the General Examina∣tion here, of the Manners of the Age, and we shou'd find, that it is the most necessary Thing in the World, that Custom shou'd allow Men to go on in a Method of Speaking without Signification.—That Abundance of the most Common Part of Humane Conversation shou'd be interlac'd with these Non-Entities in Speech: That as they are Ornaments in Style, and Useful Articles in Founding the most Essential Parts of Speaking, we cannot be without them.—The Reason is, Long Experience has found it necessary, and they are thus understood in the Sence of the Nation: More particularly, In Friendship, in Keep∣ing Secrets, in Treaties of Accommodation, in Recon∣ciliations of Differences, in Acknowledging Obligations, in Protestations of Gratitude, in New Acquaintan∣ces, in Seeking Favours, but above all, in Matters of Love, Gallantry, and Paying of Debts: I say, long Experience has found, that Oaths, Assevera∣tions,
and the Deepest Imprecations, without the least Intent or Meaning either to keep or break them, must be made Use of in such Things as these.—They are thought necessary to fill up the Vacancies of Elocution, supply the Defect of Language, assist the Passions, appear instead of Sincerity, and the like; in all which 'tis not at all requisite, that any manner of Meaning shou'd go along with them.

There are innumerable Examples to illustrate this,—and many a Votary to a Party has left us their Dying Testimony of it at the Gallows, of which Coleman was a Famous Instance in the last Age,—has been so in this, and FƲLLER, they say, is a living Witness a∣gainst Dr. Sacheverell for the like.

To bring it home to our Point, Custom hav∣ing thus legitimated this Practice, and Swearing and Jesting being the same Thing in the Sence of the Nation,—It seems strange, that our foolish People should object against the Inconsistency of any Part of our Modern Oaths, I mean, in Publick Matters, such as, of Merchants taking Custom-House Oaths, which are become insigni∣ficant to a Proverb; Citizens taking the Oath of a Freeman, which 'tis impossible for some of them to keep; Assessors and Commissioners in Taxes take Oaths, which they never think of again. Men swear off Taxes, swear to Accounts, and swear upon Juries; swear when they go into Offices, and swear when they go out; swear to the QUEEN, and swear at the QUEEN;—and what is all this, but to tell us, that Custom has taken off the Sanction of Oaths, and esta∣blish'd this for a Law, That You are to take them, just as they that swear them, mean them, viz. for nothing at all.

From Oaths to Men, let us come to the Oath of God, aud see if that has any greater Force, we see it how corruptly soever of late de∣scended to serve Parties and publick Interests, and therefore, contrary to its Institution, plac'd as a Test of Civil Distinction, a Key, the De∣vil, they say, has the Lock, to Civil Preferments, an Introduction to publick Employment, a Sup∣port to Parties, and a Property to Hypocrites; and what's the Language of all this, but that it really signifies Nothing,—is receiv'd with∣out Thinking, administer'd without Meaning, and stands for a Cypher.

And now Good People, having laid down this New System in all our Politicks, it is, as I said before to you, a Test of its Usefulness: Thus, By this Philosophy we can solve all the strange Phaenomena in our Politicks, which have so long puzzl'd our People, nd laid stumbling Blocks in the Way of Honest Men. For Example,
By this is made clear the Difficulty of Peoples Swearing to the Government, and Abjuring the Pretender, and yet Acting for his Interest, Drink∣ing his Health, and Owning him as their Sove∣reign.

By this is reconcil'd the Difficulty of the Mayor and Magistrates of M—bearing the Sword and Mace of Queen ANNE, and being Her Humble Servants all the Week, and yet going in their Formalities every Sabbath-Day to the Jacobite Meeting-House, where they pray Openly for the Restoration of the Pretender, whom they have Abjur'd.
By this is reconcil'd Damming the Tollera∣tion, and yet not blaming the Indulgence to Tender Consciences.

By this is made clear the Consistency of
the Doctrine of Hereditary Right, and Non-Resistance, with the Act of Succession, and the Revolution, and as I said before, many other Phaenomena, which, in themselves admit of no Demonstration.

CƲSTOM has declar'd, that all those Poli∣tick Oaths are taken as having no Significa∣tion; That we are to understand them, and the Takers of them to have no Meaning at all, and that they pass for Nothing; this being the Sence of the Nation.

On these Accounts they cannot be said to deceive us, for that we have nothing more to expect from them, than we ought to ex∣pect from People, that swear without Meaning, and look upon Oaths to have no Signification.

It cannot be forgotten here, that this re∣conciles the Endeavours some People use, as expect the Overthrow of the Tolleration, the Rupture of the Union, and the Dissolving the Establish'd Succession, notwithstanding her Ma∣jesty's Sacred Promise frequently given from the Throne to Support, and Defend them, and to Maintain the first of them inviolably.

It is evident, these Gentlemen take all these Sacred Pledges of Honour given by Her Majesty, to be like their own Swearing,—viz. to be taken for NOTHING, to have no Manner of Signification, so to be meant at first, and at last;—and that this is the Sence of the Nation.

It is farther evident, that in their Offering to put the Queen's Undoubted Title to the Crown, upon Her Majesty's Hereditary, not Parliamen∣tary Right; at the same Time offering no∣thing against the Legitimacy of the Pretender, they wou'd have Her Majesty believe, Her ha∣ving
NO RIGHT AT ALL, is the Sence of the Nation.

These Phaenomena in our Politick Philosophy, are solv'd very readily by this Doctrine of the Sovereignty of Custom, to establish the Mean∣ing, or No-Meaning of Speech, and to legiti∣mate the No-Meaning of the most Solemn Ac∣tions in the World.

This brings us down to the most clear De∣monstration, that any Man can desire of such a new advanc'd System, and I shall bring you abundant Testimony from all Parts of this Na∣tion, when in their most Solemn Applications to their Princes, the Good People of England have no other Testimony of their Sincerity and Honesty, either to God, their Sovereign, or themselves, than that they had no Mean∣ing at all in what they said.

This is to be found, or, at least, to be search'd for in the Famous Addresses, which upon sundry Occasions have been presented to our Princes from the Good People of England; particularly those in the late King Jame's Time, upon the Subject of the Birth of the Pretender, the taking off the Penal Laws and Test, and the bringing Papists into Employment; not ex∣cluding some now presented, and presenting to Her Majesty, by several Sorts of People, on the Behalf of the Corrupted Doctrines of Here∣ditary Right, Non-Resistance, Dissolving Parlia∣ments, &c.

Perhaps some People may alledge, that there has been a little Meaning in the Heads of the People in these Cases. But as such pretending Advocates will be brought to acknowledge those Meanings, to be absurd Contradictions to one another; inconsistent with Honour▪ Liberty, Con∣stitution
and Religion; and particularly, the Sorts of Addresses One with Another; I cannot but think the kindest as well as easiest to be demonstrated Truth we can say of them is, that they had no Meaning at all; that they were design'd by themselves to pass for nothing, re∣ceiv'd so by their Princes, and that this Opi∣nion of them has always been the Sense of the Nation.

However that any One may enter into the Enquiry, and tell us what they think: Whe∣ther it can be possible the People cou'd mean any Thing in these Addresses; and if they had any Meaning what it was: I shall present the Reader with a few of both the Kinds, set One against Another;—As to the Meaning or No-Meaning of the first Parcel, I shall evidence what I alledge, of their having been design'd to pass for nothing by their Authors from the Consequences. As to the second Sort, I shall leave them to the Sence of the Nation, to judge them by their Probability.

In my Opinion, Time has made it appear, that Addressing in King Jame's Time, had no Meaning at all, other than a meer Pulling off the Cap, which we do to any Body we meet, with Your Servant Mr. Such a One, which really passes for just nothing at all; for if the Man was to go to the Gallows the next Day, you have nothing to say to him.—So it was the Fashion just then, to say any Thing which they thought their Prince wou'd be pleas'd with; to do any Thing he bid them; to thank him for every Thing he did, whether for or against them.—As to Liberty, Priviledges, Laws, Protestant Religion, and such like Things, they never troubled their Heads with them, nor
cou'd without infinite Scandal to their Sences, be said to have any Meaning at all about them—Thus they thank him for His Standing Army, tho' they knew it was rais'd to enslave them; for His Dispensing Declaration, tho' they knew it trampled upon the Laws: They sacrific'd the Penal Laws and Test, tho' it was evident, it was in Favour of Papists only: And they pro∣mis'd for their Parliament Men that they shou'd in all Things comply with His Desires, tho' that must effectually destroy the very Being of Par∣liaments.

After all these Fine Words, these very Ad∣dressors never perform'd one of these Things, and the kindest Thing I can say of them is, that they never intended it.—Not that I am reproaching them at all for Cheats and Hy∣pocrites, that wheedled and deluded their Princes, as I know some do; that first made him believe they wou'd be ridden into any Thing, that they wou'd submit to any Thing, wou'd have been as passive as they talk'd of, and wou'd really subject themselves, their Liberties, Laws and Religion to His Absolute Will: No, No! The good People were honester than so.—The Error lay here; the Thing was a customary Piece of Extravagance, and the King took them to be in Earnest.—Sir, Your most Obedient Ser∣vant, says a Man to me in the Street; if I shou'd bid him go of an Errand for me, he wou'd answer, What, Sir, do you take me for a Porter! Your Majesty's Royal Dispensing Right, says one Set of Gentlemen. We will choose such Mem∣bers as y ur Majesty shall recommend, say another. If the King puts it home to them, they an∣swer, What! Does His Majesty think we are all Slaves! The Matter is very plain, The Thing
stands for nothing; if the King took them to be in Earnest, that was His Fault, they gave Him very little Reason for it; they spoke Words of Course, Things usual in all Times, from Sub∣jects to Sovereigns; and which had nothing in them more than Words, and never use to be understood any farther.—Words of Custom, the Language of Good Manners, that they were to stand for nothing was the Sence of the Nation, and if he had had his Usual Sences a∣bout Him, they wou'd have stood for nothing with Him.

Thus King James was serv'd with His Addres∣sors, I cou'd have brought a List of the Universal Addressings of the Nation just in this Manner, and ev'ry Way as extravagant, to Richard Crom∣well of Old, not Two Months before they de∣pos'd him: Ditto to King CHARLES the Se∣cond, when they abhorr'd Petitioning; when they gave up their Charters, Laws and National Priviledges to Him: Ditto to King WILLIAM, upon Occasions quite Differing, and Contradic∣ting to them all;—and all these wou'd be evident Testimonies that Addressing the Sove∣reigns in England from the Towns, Corpora∣tions, Counties, Grand Juries, &c. has for ma∣ny Years past, been reckoned to stand for no∣thing; and is therefore, by Custom determin'd to be of no Manner of Signification.

I hope, the Reader will understand me tomean of such Addresses only, as have been made in Former Days: As to those now made, which are calculated to Things of a higher Nature, such as Telling Her Majesty what Title She reigns by, as if She did not know before; Promising to choose such Parliament-Men, as shall GIVE ƲP Parliamentary Right; Letting Her Majesty know
how joyful they shall be to have the Parliament dissolv'd, especally such of them as have Reason to apprehend Parliamentary Justice; letting Her Ma∣jesty know, they desire to bring in the Pretender, and that, therefore, they hope She will change Her Ministry.

As to these great Things, it seems to me, these People, much better than any before them, speak as plainly to us as possible, that they would be understood to have NO MEANING. It would be the highest Presumption in the World, for Subjects to talk in this Manner to their Sove∣raign; and they could not but expect, even from a most mild, and mercifull Prince the ut∣most Resentment: And I can make no Question, but they would most certainly meet with it, were it not, that they know, and take it for granted, that these Things call'd Addresses, have always been allow'd to stand for nothing, have been desigu'd so by the People that sign'd them, been receiv'd as such by the Persons di∣rected to, and allow'd for such in the Sence of the Nation.

Here follows some select Addresses, and Passa∣ges out of other Addresses, faithfully Collected from the Great Body of the Nothing-Signifying Addresses aforesaid, Presented to the Late King JAMES, not many Months before His Abdication, being the same Year of the Revolution, and which serve as a Proof of what has been laid down as above. And also,

Some select Addresses, and Passages out of other Addresses, from the same Places, faith∣fully Collected from the Great Body of Ad∣dresses, lately Printed, and said to be Pre∣sented,—whose Similitude to the Former
in their Eminent Signification, is left to the Determination of Time, and the Judgment of the most Charitable Reader.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
DIV3.P: WE Your most Faithful and Truly Loyal Sub∣jects, the Mayor, Recorder, Aldermen, Common-Coun∣cil and Burghers of the An∣cient Corporation of Cam∣bridge, do Humbly cast at the Feet of Your Sacred Majesty, our Unfeigned Thanks for Your most Gracious Declara∣tion of Indulgence, which, Your Majesty has been plea∣sed, with much Condescen∣sion to repeat, giving it a double Strength by Your Royal Word; so that none that are truly Loyal, can doubt of the Performance of Your Majesty's most Graci∣ous Promise, or refuse to make their thankful Addres∣ses for it.
When, therefore, Your Royal Wisdom shall think fit to call a Parliament, we,

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Humble Address of the Mayor, Re∣corder, Aldermen, and Burgesses of the Corporation of Cam∣bridge.
DIV4.P: WE Your Majesty's Loyal Subjects, being deeply sensible of the Inva∣luable Happiness we enjoy, under the Influence of Your Auspicious Reign, cannot but think our selves in Duty bound to express in the most respectful Manner, our hear∣ty Zeal for the Security and Honour of Your Majesty's Sacred Person and Govern∣ment, especially, at a Time, when that Natural Reve∣rence, which is indispensably due to Princes, is in Danger of being diminish'd by the Factious Notions of the Peo∣ples Power, and of Gover∣nors being liable to the Cen∣sure and Coertion of their Subjects, so boldly vented, and industriously cultivated by a Libertine and Republi∣can Faction.

DIV3.P: Your Majesty's most Loyal Subjects entirely engage our selves, and the utmost of our Endeavours for the Election of such Members, as will Heartily concur with that Divine Principle of Your Majesty, That Mens Consci∣ences ought not to be forced in Matters of Religion, nor they distinguished in the Service of their Country by other Tests than that of Loyalty.

Wherefore, the many Bles∣sings we enjoy under Your Sacred Majesty, engage us in Daily Prayer to Almighty God, that as Your Royal Vir∣tues exceed all Example, so Your Reign above Compa∣rison, may be the Longest; nor may it end 'till a Prince of WALES born of Your Roy∣al Consort, our most Graci∣ous Queen, hath learn'd by a long Experience, the most Heroick Greatness of Your Royal Mind, in Testimony whereof, we have Unani∣mously caus'd our Common Seal to be affix'd hereunto, this 28th Day of May, in the Fourth Year of Your Maje∣sty's Reign. Anno Domini, 1688.

DIV4.P: We humbly beg Leave, to lay before Your Majesty, our Abhorrence and Detestation of these Mischievous, Rebel∣lious Principles, which na∣turally tend to undermine the Fundamentals of Go∣vernment, and shake the Thrones of Princes, and to assure Your Majesty, that our utmost Care and Dili∣gence shall be employ'd to give Effectual Evidence of our sincere Concern for the Support and Preservation of the Best of Constitutions, and the Best of QUEENS, by Continuing to choose such Representatives, who we are assur'd by their known Re∣gard for the Right of Princes, will oppose those bold En∣croachments upon the Royal Prerogative, which, if not Timely prevented, will un∣der the Pretence of Liberty, introduce a fatal Licentious∣ness and Disorder.

And may that Great God, by whom Kings reign, so dis∣pose the Minds of all Degrees of Your Majesty's Subjects, that they may entertain very respectful Sentiments of that Authority, deriv'd from a Power superior to any upon Earth, and signalize them∣selves in all Instances of Chri∣stian Obedience, and True English Loyalty under Your Majesty's Gracious Admini∣stration.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
To the King's Most Excellent Majesty.

The Humble and Ʋna∣nimous Address of Your Majesty's Ju∣stices of the Peace, at the General Quar∣ter Sessions of the Peace, Holden at Leeds, for the West-Riding of the County of York, this 12th Day of July; in the Fourth Year of Your Majesty's Reign.
DIV3.P: MAY it please Your Sacred Majesty, to suffer us, Your most Loyal Subjects, moved by the most ardent Affection, profound∣est Duty, and truest Interest; to congratulate You, our, and the Three Kingdoms Happiness, in the Birth of a Prince, humbly praying the God of Heaven, for Life, Health, and Prosperity to Your Majesty, His Royal Highness, and Your Royal Consort; with the Addition of whatever may contribute to Your and their Happi∣ness here. And after a long

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.

The Humble Address of the Justices of the Peace, the Grand Ju∣ry, and other Gentle∣men, at the General Sessions of the Peace, held for the West-Riding of the Coun∣ty of York, at Pon∣tefract in the said County, on the 18th of April; in the Ninth Year of Your Majesty's Reign.
DIV4.P: WE Your Majesty's most Dutiful Subjects, and Sons of that Church, which hath always taught us to Fear God and Honour the Queen, and not to meddle with those that are giv'n to change; be∣ing deeply sensible, that we live in an Age, when Men of all Sects in Religion join with Men of no Religion, to blas∣pheme God, despise Domini∣ons, and speak evil of Digni∣ties, Preaching and Printing Doctrines and Positions, e∣qually Destructive to the Rites of the Church, and the just Prerogative of the Crown.

DIV3.P: Reign over us, may Your Majesty inherit an Eternal Crown in a Better King∣dom, and may there never want one of Your Royal Line to sway the Scepter of these Kingdoms 'till Time shall be no more, is the most servent, sincere and unfeign∣ed Prayer of

DIV4.P: Humbly beg Leave with the greatest Sincerity, to as∣sure Your Majesty, that we abhor, detest and abjure all Atheistical and Schismatical, Antimonarchical, and Sedi∣tious Principles and Prac∣tices: And as Your Majesty has always made the Laws the Rule of Your Govern∣ment, so We, in our several Stations, shall make the same Laws the Measure of our Allegiance, which does not depend upon the Will of the People, but is founded upon the Laws of God, and is an Essential Part of our Consti∣tution, which Constitution, under Your Majesty's Go∣vernment both in Church and State, as the One Mo∣narchical, the Other Epis∣copal, with the Protestant Succession of the Crown, as by Law Limited and Esta∣blish'd, we will to the ut∣most of our Power, support, maintain and defend,

And our most Humble Prayers are, that God would extend Your Majesty's Life and Reign, as far beyond the Common Term of either, as Your Vertues are uncom∣mon, exceed and outshine all others, and may each Year be Crown'd with fresh Instan∣ces of Divine Goodness to Your Majesty, Your Allies▪ and these Kingdoms.
And we will endeavour to

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
To the King's Most Excellent Majesty,

The Humble Address of Your Majesty's Loyal and Dutiful Subjects, the Grand Jury of Your City and County of Exeter, held at the Guild-Hall of the said City, the 23d Day of April, in the Fourth Year of His Majesty's Reign, being the An∣niversary Day, solem∣niz'd for Your Maje∣sty's Coronation.
DIV3.P: SInce it hath pleased the King of Kings to bring Your Majesty to the Crown, and seat You on the Throne of Your Illustrious Ancestors on this Day, we thought it our Duty, not only to thank

DIV4.P: choose such Representatives in Parliament, whose Loyalty to the Crown, and good Af∣fection to the Church, hath been conspicuous, not only in themselves, but their Ance∣stors.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.

The Humble Address of the Mayor, Aldermen, High-Sheriff & Com∣mon Council of the City Exon, and of the Gentlemen return'd, to serve as a Grand Jury for the said City and County of the said City of Exon, at the Assizes, held at the Guild-Hall of the City, on the Third Day of April, 1710.
DIV4.P: WE Your Majesty's most Dutiful, and Loyal Subjects, being Truly sensible of our great Happiness, in that we are Members of the Church of England, as by Law Establish'd, shall always

DIV3.P: the Great God of Heaven for this Universal Blessing, which We did perform, with Hearts full of unfeign'd Joy, and throughly sensible of that great Happiness, which it hath pleased the over-Ru∣ling Providence to bless us with, under Your Majesty's most Gracious and Merciful Government. But as We are bound to thank God for this great Blessing, so we judge our selves likewise en∣gag'd by all the Obligations imaginable, to return our Thanks to Your Sacred Ma∣jesty God's true Vicegerent, whose Actions have surpriz'd any Thing that History cou'd yet afford us, and whose Gracious and Unparallell'd Declaration for Liberty of Conscience, hath come up to that Agreeableness of Divi∣nity it self, who hath said of Kings, I have made ye Gods. That You, Great Sir, have exceeded all Princes in that high and transcendent Cha∣racter. We crave Leave, most Gracious Sovereign, to render unto Your Majesty, our most unfeigned Thanks for those fresh Obligations, and Priviledges lately grant∣ed to this your Ancient and Loyal City in our new Char∣ter, humbly assuring Your Majesty, that whenever you please to call a Parliament, we shall give our Assistance in choosing such Members, as we doubt not, will readily

DIV4.P: concur with your Majesty in a tender Regard for its Pro∣sperity, and by Divine As∣sistance, conscientiously prac∣tice its most pure and holy Doctrines, and we Humbly beg Leave, to assure Your Majesty, our Rightful and Lawful Queen and Gover∣nor, that we will inviolably pay Your Majesty that Duty and Obedience, which our Oaths oblige us to, and our Church hath taught us to be Your Due.

And we do heartily detest and abhor, and in our several Stations, shall zealously dis∣countenance all those Blas∣phemous, Heretical, Schis∣matical, Latitudinarian and Republican Principles and Positions, with which some evil-disposed Persons, have of late, endeavour'd to de∣prave the Christian Faith, to corrupt the Minds of Your Majesty's Subjects, and to un∣dermine our Excellent Con∣stitution, both in Church and State.

And as often as Your Ma∣jesty shall be pleas'd to call us by our Representatives to Parliament, we shall endea∣vour to be so represented, that as far as in us lies, Your Majesty and the Publick Oc∣casions, may be vigorously supply'd, Your Royal Digni∣ty and Prerogative, the Pro∣testant Succession, and every other Part of the Constitu∣tion faithfully maintain'd, and

DIV3.P: concur to perpetuate your great and good Work, which Your Majesty, to your Eter∣nal Honour and Glory, have so happily begun. May the Great God of Heaven make Your Majesty's Reign long, and prosperous over us, and grant Your Majesty, and Your Royal Consort a nu∣merous and lasting Issue, that as this Generation hath great Cause to bless God for You, so future Generations may rise up, and call You, and Your Royal Progeny for ever blessed. So Pray hear∣tily,

CLOSER.SALUTE: Your MAJESTY's Most Loyal and Dutiful Subjects.

DIV4.P: the Doctrines and Principles of the Church of England, de∣liver'd Unblemish'd in Poste∣rity.
We beseech Almighty God, to multiply his Bles∣sings on Your Majesty, and thro' Your Majesty's Admi∣nistration on Your People.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
To the King's Most Excellent Majesty,
The Humble Address of the Mayor, Aldermen and Common Council of Your Majesty's An∣cient and Loyal City of Hereford.
DIV3.P: We beseech Your Ma∣jesty, to suffer us (a∣mongst the rest of Your Loyal Subjects) thus Hum∣bly and Publickly to express our grateful Sense of that Happy Addition, which it has pleased GOD to make to the Royal Family, by giving Your Majesty and Your Kingdoms, the desirable Blessing of a Prince, to inherit Your Roy∣al Virtues and Dominions; and Humbly pray, that Your Royal Issue may grow more and more numerous, to suc∣ceed to your Imperial Crown in all Future Generations.
We likewise crave Your Majesty's Leave (once more) Thankfully to acknowledge those invaluable Blessings, we

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
To the Queen's Most Excellent Majesty,
The Humble Address of the Mayor, Aldermen and Chief Citizens of the City of Hereford, in Common-Council Assembled.
DIV4.P: AS it hath been our Hap∣piness hitherto, to have been by all Your Royal Pre∣decessors accounted a Loyal City, and to have receiv'd several Distinguishing Marks of their Royal Favour for the same; so we hope to trans∣mit that honest Character down to Posterity: And, therefore, cannot without extreme Horror, reflect on the Industrious Application that has of late been us'd, to vilify and abolish that Truly Christian Doctrine of Obedience and Submission to Your Princely Crown and Dignity, which our Church most strictly enjoins, and is the strongest Support of the Throne; and in its Place to

DIV3.P: enjoy under Your Majesty's most Gracious Government.

And do most Humbly as∣sure Your Majesty, that as this Place has heretofore been plunder'd, and ran∣sack'd again and again, for their unalterable Fidelity to the Crown, so we will ever owe Dutiful and Loyal Obe∣dience to Your Majesty, Your Heirs, and Successors.
In Testimony whereof, we have hereunto put our Com∣mon Seal, at the Guild-Hall of Your said City.

DIV4.P: introduce that damnable Po∣sition of Resistance, the dis∣mal Consequence of which, Your Majesty's Royal Grand∣father, of Ever-blessed and Glorious Memory, and these Realms have been too fatally sensible of.

And to Perpetuate these Pernicious Principles, and transmit them to Future Ge∣nerations, there are Set up and Propagated, in many Parts of this Kingdom, those Nurseries of Rebellion and Faction call'd Academies, in Opposition to our Two Fa∣mous Universities, which is an Innovation as much con∣trary to Law, as the Do∣ctrine they teach is destruc∣tive to both Church and State.

We crave Leave, there∣fore (most Dread Sove∣reign) Humbly to declare our utmost Detestation of all such Vile and Insolent Pro∣ceedings, and to assure Your Majesty, that we will with our Lives and Fortunes, not only Assert and Maintain Your Majesty's Just, and Rightful Dominion over us, in its Fullest and most An∣cient Legal Extent, the Succession in the most Il∣lustrious House of Hannover, but also our Holy Aposto∣lical Church, together with those Laws she is at present guarded with, that neither Atheists, Papists, or those Re∣publican,

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
To the King's Most Excellent Majesty,
The Humble Address of the Mayor, Aldermen, Bayliffs and Citizens of the City of Car∣lisle.
DIV3.P: BEing now at Liberty, by the late Regulation made here, to Address our selves unto Your Majesty, we beg Leave to return our Late, but Unseigned Thanks for Your Majesty's Most Gra∣cious Declaration of Indul∣gence, which we will endea∣vour to maintain and sup∣port against all Opposers: We likewise, thank Your Majesty for Your Royal Ar∣my, which really is both the Honour and Safety of the

DIV4.P: Factious Hypocrites, whose restless Endeavours are incessantly employ'd to accomplish the utter Ruin of our Church and Consti∣tution, may ever prevail a∣gainst them.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Humble Address of the Burgesses, and Inhabitants of the Burrough of Minehead, in the County of Somer∣set.
DIV4.P: SInce your Majesty has been pleased to allow your subjects thus to ad∣dress you, with their Ac∣knowledgment of your Su∣premacy, and a Tender of their Duty towards you, we your most Dutiful and Loy∣al Subjects, the Inhabitants of your Ancient Burrough of Minehead, humbly beg Leave to take this Oppor∣tunity, to assure your Ma∣jesty, that we do from our Hearts believe your un∣doubted

DIV3.P: Nation; let the Tekelites think, and say what they will. And when Your Majesty in your Great Wisdom, shall think fit to call a Parliament, we will choose such Mem∣bers, as shall certainly con∣cur with your Majesty, in Repeating and Taking off the Penal Laws and Tests, and not hazard the Election of any Person, who hath any Ways declared in Favour of those Canibal Laws, surely they do not consider, what a Sovereign Prince by His Royal Power, may do, that oppose Your Majesty in so Gracious and Glorious a Work! A Work, which Hea∣ven smiles upon, and will re∣ward with no less Blessing, we hope, than a PRINCE of WALES, that there may never want of Your Royal Issue to sway the Scepter so long as the Sun and Moon endure, that Your Majesty's Reign may be Long and Pro∣sperous, and Blessed with Vi∣ctories over ill Your Ene∣mies, are the daily Prayers of

CLOSER.SALUTE: Great Sir, Your Majesty's Most Obedien: and Duti∣ful Subjects.

DIV4.P: doubted Title to the Crown of these Realms, and that we will support and defend your Sacred Person and Go∣vernment, with the Protest∣ant Succession as by Law Li∣mited and Establish'd, ev'n with an Oblation of our Lives and Fortunes, as well against all treacherous and secret Enemies, as those that are publick and declared.

And here, out of our a∣bundant Concern for your Majesty, we cannot omit to observe how this Republican Principle of Resistance is of late openly taught, and main∣tain'd, a Principle, that even in the Memories of some a∣mongst us, caus'd an unnatu∣ral Rebellion against the best of Princes, your Royal Grand∣father, subverted the Monar∣chy, the wisest of Govern∣ours, and ruin'd that Church, whose Doctrine is built up∣on the Prophets and A post∣les, whose Government is truly A postolical, and in all its Essential Parts of Divine Institution, and likewise, to declare, that we do detest, and abhor such a Factious and Pernicious Notion, a No∣tion ridiculous in its Nature, inconsistent with Reason and Scripture, tho' in Case of TYRANNT and OPPRESSION▪ and as we declare our just Abhorrence of that abomi∣nable Notion of Resistance, which is the more abomina∣ble,

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
A Passage from the Ber∣wick Address.
DIV3.P: WHerefore, Most Dread Sovereign, to give You the Earnest of a greater Har∣vest,

DIV4.P: because we live under your Majesty's Government, the mildest of Governments, and as we assure your Maje∣sty, to defend your Sacred Person and Government in the State, so do we promise your Majesty, well knowing, that the Prosperity of them both are inseparable, that it shall be our constant Care to defend that in the Church, with all its Apostolical Doc∣trines and Discipline, the one Monarchical, the other Epis∣copal.

And to that End we shall be always ready to discounte∣nance, and suppress all such wicked Tenents and Practi∣ces, as will mislead us into Atheism, Heresy and Schism, and when your Majesty shall, in your Princely Wisdom, judge it proper, we shall still continue to chose such Pa∣triots, to represent us in Par∣liament; as shall be eminent∣ly Loyal Subjects to your Ma∣jesty, and constant Commu∣nicants of our Establish'd Church. That God, &c.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
A Passage from the Hin∣don Address.
DIV4.P: WE cannot, then, but wonder at the daring Insolence of a restless Set of

DIV3.P: we hereby most Hearti∣ly and Sincerely declare, that we will on all Occasions, de∣fend Your Majesty's Sacred Person and Government with the utmost of our Lives and Fortunes against all Oppo∣sers whatsoever: And that whensoever, it shall please your Majesty, in your Prince∣ly Wisdom, to call a Parlia∣ment, we do hereby Unani∣mously Agree to choose for Burgesses, such as have Your Majesty's Gracious Recom∣mendations, and shall concur with Your Majesty's known Pleasure, in Annulling and Abolishing the Penal Laws and Test, that so Your said Gracious Declaration may likewise be the True Sense of all your Subjects in an Act of Parliament.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
The Humble Address of the Mayor, Aldermen, and Inhabitants of the City of Bath.
DIV3.P: NO sooner did the Happy News of the Prince's Birth reach our Ears, but we of this Place

DIV4.P: Men, who give Protection and Encouragment to those Hainous Crimes of Schism in the Church, and Resistance to Princes, sowing Daily their Heretical, and Anti∣monarchical Principles in e∣very Corner of this Kingdom, openly Renouncing your Ma∣jesty's Hereditary Right to the Crown, paring by De∣grees Your Title, as if in Time they design'd to leave none.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Humble Address of the Mayor, Aldermen, and Inhabitants of the City of Bath.
DIV4.P: OUR unfeigned Zeal and Affection for Your Majesty's most Sacred Per∣son, the Protestant Succes∣sion,

DIV3.P: thought it our Duty in a more especial Manner, to be early in the Return of of our Praises to the Al∣mighty, for so great a Bles∣sing upon us, and Your Three Kingdoms, and in Congratulating Your Ma∣jesty, and Your Royal Con∣sort, of being the Joyful Parents of So GOOD a Son; a Gift, which the whole Nation ought to esteem, as the Reward of Heaven upon that continu'd Series of Goodness and Indulgence, which Your Majesty hath ever since the Beginning of Your most Auspicious Reign extended to Your Subjects, particularly that of Your Compassionate De∣claration for Liberty of Con∣science, whereby, as You are pleas'd to suspend the Execution of all Penal Laws in Matters of Reli∣gion, and the requiring of any Oaths or Tests. So do we upon our Allegiance to You, our Sovereign, promise and engage, that whenso∣ever Your Majesty shall think fit to call a Parlia∣ment, such of us, as shall have Power of Electing, will choose none to serve therein, but who will give us full Assurance, that they will endeavour the Total Abrogation of them.

DIV4.P: and the Church of England as by Law Estab∣lish'd; obliges us at this Time, to assure Your Ma∣jesty, that we are ready to sacrifice all that's dear to us in their Defence, in Opposition as well to those Pernicious Principles of Faction and Sedition, as to all Irreligious, Hypocritical and Trayterous Practices, the natural and certain Consequences thereof.

We are Madam, sur∣priz'd, that any of Your Majesty's Subjects, (if they may be so nam'd,) shou'd be such Enemies to Your Majesty, Your Crown and Prerogative, as to dare to deny Your Hereditary Right to the Throne of Your Ancestors; any so wicked, as to justify that Horrid Murder of that Blessed Martyr, Your Royal Grand-Father, and vilify those Doctrines of our Church, and Holy Religion, which are our only Security a∣gainst the like detestable Attempts for the future.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
To the King's Most Excellent Majesty.
The Humble Address of the High-Sheriff, Justices of the Peace, and the Grand Jury of the County of Oxon, at the Ge∣neral Assizes held at Oxford, the 18th Day of July, 1688.
DIV3.P: AS We are sensible the best Addresses that Subjects can make, are the Returns of Duty and Obe∣dience to their Princes Com∣mands, We shou'd not have presum'd upon this Appli∣cation, but that full Hearts, like full Banks will overflow. The Blessing God Almigh∣ty hath been pleas'd to bestow on Your Majesty, and this Realm, by send∣ing a PRINCE of WALES, is a Happiness too large to be contain'd within the narrow Compass of our Breasts, wherefore, We cou'd not but join in our Particulars to the univer∣sal

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE▪

OPENER.SALUTE: May it please Your Most Sacred Majesty.

DIV4.P: WE the High-Sheriff, Grand Jury, Justices of the Peace, Deputy-Lieutenants, Gentlemen of the County of Oxon, do u∣nanimously beg Leave to express our extream Grief that the seditious Principles so openly maintain'd and allow'd of late, shou'd make it necessary for all Your Loyal Subjects to give Your Majesty fresh Assu∣rances of their Inviolable Duty and Affection, and to declare their Abhorrence of all Doctrines, which al∣low Subjects to Resist their Sovereign, which are pro∣pagated in Defiance of the

DIV3.P: Joy of the whole King∣dom, receive, therefore, Great Sir, the Congratulations flowing from Hearts full of Loyalty, which Your Majesty shall always find, whenever Your Commands shall call us to a Perfor∣mance, and hope, there will be none, who here∣after will dare to frown on Your Royal Designs, since Heaven smiles on all Your Actions, whither, We will send fresh our Daily-Prayers for Your Majesty's and the Prince's long Life, and Happiness, and hope, by constant soliciting the Divine Goodness, to obtain a Second Blessing to this Nation, and that the Queen may have a Duke of York, for which, let the Three Kingdoms join, 'till Hea∣ven hears our Prayers, and all concur with us in say∣ing Amen.

DIV4.P: Laws of God, and of this Realm, and which are ut∣terly inconsistent with the Quier and Subsistance of Government. We shall al∣ways be firm to those Prin∣ciples of Duty to our So∣vereign, which we have profess'd, and which have been taught in the most Perilous Times, by that Famous University, in whose Neighbourhood we live, and we shall endeavour to trans∣mit the same to our Poste∣rity, that their Loyalty may be Hereditary, as Your Majesty's Title is to the Throne of Your Ances∣tors.

Tho' we were astonish'd to see the most factious Po∣sitions reviv'd, and propa∣gated under the best and mildest of Governments, yet we the less wonder at it, since it is easie to observe, that the most o∣pen Patrons of Resistance are equally Encouragers of Blasphemy and Profaness, and that the Poyson'd Ar∣rows, which have been shot as well against God, as His Vicegerent, have come out of the same Quiver.
There shall be nothing wanting in us, to restrain the Insolence, and defeat the Malice of the Enemies of God, and of Your Ma∣jesty; and when Your Majesty, to the extream

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
To the King's Most Excellent Majesty.
The Humble Address of the Clergy of the County Palatinate of Chester, who Pub∣lish'd the Late Gra∣cious Declaration in their Churches for Liberty of Consci∣ence.
DIV3.P: WE your Majesty's most Dutiful, and Loyal Subjects well weigh∣ing what we as such, ought

DIV4.P: Joy of all your Loyal Sub∣jects, shall, in your Princely Wisdom, judge it proper to call a Parliament, we doubt not to choose such as shall truly represent this County, always eminent for its Loy∣alty, by doing all that is in their Power, to support the Just Prerogative of the Crown, the Church of Eng∣land as by Law Establish'd, the Welfare of your People, and the Protestant Succes∣sion, as settled in the Il∣lustrious House of Hannover.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
To the Queen's Most Excellent Majesty.
The Humble Address of the Ʋniversity Oxford.
DIV4.P: WE your Majesty's most Dutiful and Loyal Subjects, the Chancellor, Masters, and Scholars of

DIV3.P: to render to so Sacred, and Gracious a King, reckon'd we ow'd this, and higher Instances of our Obedience, in Pursuance of which, and of your Majesty's Order in Council, we heartily read the Declaration for Liberty of Conscience, not repining, that all other our Fellow-Subjects shou'd enjoy with us a Portion of your Roy∣al Favour. We are well aware, that many have well deserv'd, and as to the other Number, towards whom you go the Cour∣tēous, and Noblest Way of Conquering. We hope, your Mercy may be suc∣cessful, or at least, your Power will preserve you safe. But if the Matter of the Declaration were not according to our Wishes▪ yet the Establishing of it is according to our Duty, since it is issu'd our from the express Prerogative of your Supremacy over us, and we are requir'd by what is Statute-Law, the Rubrick of our Liturgy, to Publish what is enjoyn'd by the King, or our Bishop, (whose Care herein was remarkable) as much as what was prescribed in the Rules of this Book. So that we cannot but with Trouble of Mind hear of the Proceedings of the Se∣ven Bishops, who, tho' they

DIV4.P: the University of Oxon. being deeply sensible of the many great and inestimable Blessings God has bestow'd upon this Church and Na∣tion, in placing, and pre∣serving your Majesty up∣on the Throne of your Royal Ancestors, must beg Leave in this Publick and Solemn Manner, to give our Thanks to Almighty God, and to assure your Majesty of the Continuance of our Inviolable Duty, and Allegiance to your Sacred Person, and Government. And as that Duty will ne∣ver suffer us to call in Question any Title, by which your Majesty holds your Crown, particularly that which is Hereditary. So it will never permit us to give any Countenance to that Popish, Republican Doc∣trine of Resistance of Prin∣ces, the very Mention of which at this Time, under the Best of Queens ought to be detested and abhorr'd.

Wē most Humbly pray your Majesty, also to be∣lieve that we do, and will always use our utmost En∣deavours to promote the Peace and Quiet of your Reign, by teaching and en∣couraging such Principles, as may tend to true Virtue, Piety and Loyalty. 'Tis, therefore, not without very great Trouble we observe,

DIV3.P: tenderly promis'd the Dis∣senters something, yet re∣fus'd to do their Part a∣bout the Declaration, left they shou'd be Parties to it, which Reason, we with due Modesty, (and relying upon a Higher Authority) esteem insufficient, seeing the Parliament of 62 did not think the Reading of the Commou-Prayer was ap∣proving of it, without As∣sent and Consent publickly declar'd.

We therefore, in all Sub∣mission become earnest, tho' too mean Intercessors to your Most Gracious Ma∣jesty, in Behalf of the Church of England, that the Faults of those and o∣thers may not be laid to our Charge, in whose Com∣munion there are many, and we hope there will be more, who concur in promoting the Purposes of your mild Government. We farther beg Leave, to make our Congratulations for the Happy Birth of the young Prince in His Hereditary, Successive Kingdom, we in this Palatinate, are the first Lot of Inheritance to the First-Born of our Kings, and as we have a greater Part in Him, so we have a more plentiful joy, that He is born to us, praying a long Life to Him▪ and the In∣heriting of His Royal Fa∣ther's

DIV4.P: that notwithstanding your Majesty's most Pious Care to prevent it, yet Ill Men have found Means to pro∣pagate so many Blasphe∣mous and Heretical Doc∣trines among us, which tend not more to the undermi∣ning of Religion, than they do to the Disturbance of the Civil Peace.

Neither can we at our Approaches to your Ma∣jesty, ever cease to repeat our Thanks for that great Affection you have always express'd to the Establish'd Church, which you have enrich'd by your Bounty, and adorn'd by your Pi∣ety. And when we con∣sider this Church, as fram'd most exactly according to the Primitive and Aposto∣lical Model, we cannot but with the deepest Sorrow bewail the Danger of so many deluded Souls, as are misled into the Damnable Sin of Schism, tho' we by no Means presume to dis∣approve of that Legal Im∣punity, which is allow'd to Consciences Truly Tender.

And that we may in the most effectual Manner ap∣prove our selves most Loy∣al Subjects to your Ma∣jesty, most Dutiful Sons of the Church, True Lovers of our Country, and Af∣fectionate Bretheren to our Follow-Subjects, we will use

DIV3.P: Crowns and Virtues. We hereby bind our selves to conclude tedastly,

CLOSER.SALUTE: Your Majesty's Most Devoted, obedient, and Firm Subjects, and Servants.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
The Address of the Grand Jury for the County of Hertford, July 23. 1688.
DIV3.P: HAD not a Party averse to comply with your Majesty's Gracious Inclina∣tions, been too prevalent in this County, an Address would have been sooner made to your Most Sacred Ma∣jesty, for your Most Graci∣ous Declaration of Indulgence.

DIV4.P: our utmost Care to be al∣ways Represented in Par∣liament by such Members, as will Inviolably maintain your Just Prerogative, the Succession in the Illustrious House of Hannover, the Rights of the Church, and Liberties of the Subject, the Compassing of which great Ends, will compleat the Glory of your Victo∣rious Arms, which we Pray Almighty God may conti∣nue such, 'till a Safe and Honourable Peace shall leave no farther Use of them.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Address of the Grand Jury for the County of Hertford.
DIV4.P: WE Your Majesty's most Faithful and Obedi∣ent Subjects, have with great Satisfaction observed the ma∣ny Loyal Addresses, decla∣ring their firm and Affection to Your Majesty, the Church of England, and the Protest∣ant

DIV3.P: And tho' we are too too Late, yet we hope, we shall not be unwelcome, in ma∣king a Due and Just Re∣turn of our most Humble and Hearty Thanks, and Grateful Acknowledgments, for your Majesty's Gracious Intentions to your Subjects in general, in Abrogating of the Penal Laws and Test.

We will not (like others) go about Thanking your Majesty for your Particular Favours; of Promising to maintain the Establish'd Re∣ligion of the Church of Eng∣land, but do Freely, Wil∣lingly and Unanimously give our Best Thanks in general, and without any Restriction whatsoever.

We are neither for De∣signing Evil, nor for Carry∣ing it on when it is begun, therefore, do promise our utmost Endeavours (when your Majesty shall, in your great Wisdom, think fit to call a Parliament) to choose and promote the Choosing of such Representatives, as will, in all respects, comply with your Majesty's Desires. We all Heartily thank your Majesty, for your Late Pro∣clamation against Swearing.
And Lastly, we do (with all the Joy our Hearts can wish, or Tongues express) Congratulate the Birth of the Prince of Wales, a Bles∣sing sent from Heaven for

DIV4.P: Succession, in Opposition to, and Abhorrence of all Jesuitical, Atheistical, and Schismatical Books, and Prin∣ciples of late, so boldly pub∣lish'd, and maintain'd, and industriously dispers'd a∣mong us, which Addresses have been graciously re∣ceiv'd by Your Majesty, we likewise heartily joining with the rest of our Fellow-Subjects in so grateful and necessary Declarations, do presume Humbly to give Your Majesty the same As∣surances of our inviolable Duty to Your Sacred Per∣son, of our sincere Af∣fection to the Church of England, and of our firm Resolution to maintain the protestant Succession both at Home, and Abroad.

And as Your Majesty hath often from the Throne been pleased graciously to recommend Union among all Your Subjects, we do assure Your Majesty of our sincere Endeavours to pro∣mote the same, and do hope, by our tender Re∣gard to all our Fellow-Subjects, that are under the Misfortune of Dissent∣ing from us, either to reconcile 'em to our E∣stablishment, or to create in them so much Mode∣fty, as to distinguish be∣tween a Kind Indulgence, and a Legal Establishment.

DIV3.P: the Perpetual Establishment of Liberty of Conscience. May all the Happiness of Heaven and Earth attend your Ma∣jesty, your Royal Consort, and the young Prince, and may we cease Living when we cease being

CLOSER.SALUTE: Your Majesty's most Dutiful and Loyal Subjects.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
To the King's Most Excellent Majesty,

The Humble Address of the Lord Lieutenant, Deputy-Lieutenants and Justices of the Peace of the County of Kent, at the Ge∣neral Quarter Sessi∣ons, holden at Can∣terbury, the 10th of July, 1688. for the Eastern Division of the said County.
DIV3.P: WE your Majesty's Loy∣al and Dutiful Sub∣jects, having render'd to Al∣mighty God our most sincere

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Humble Address of the Grand Jury, Deputy-Lieutenants, Justices of the Peace, and other Gentlemen and Free-holders of the County of So∣merset.
DIV4.P: WE Your Majesty's most Dutiful, and Loyal Subjects, the Grand-Jury, Deputy-Lieutenants, Justices

DIV3.P: and humble Thanksgivings, for the Ineffable Blessings be∣stow'd upon your Royal Ma∣jesty, your Kingdoms and Dominions, in the Happy Birth of a Prince. We do now (Sacred Sir) esteem it our Duty and Highest Ob∣ligation, prostrate at your Majesty's Feet, gratefully to Acknowledge, that your Majesty's Admirable Good∣ness, Piety and Justice have obtain'd from our most Cra∣cious God, this so inexpres∣sible a Blessing, the Conside∣ration whereof, as it ought, so are we considently assured it will open the Eyes of all (who are not wholly possess'd with the Spirit of Contradiction) to behold with Grateful Hearts, your Majesty's most Fatherly and Pious Care for the Welfare of your People; so that when your Majesty shall think fit to call a Parliament▪ we shall all to the utmost of our Endeavours, make Choice of such Persons to serve therein, as may unite your Subjects in Charity and Chri∣stian Correspondence, by their Unanimous Consent to the Repeal of those disuni∣ting Peul Laws and Tests, whereby Divisions and Ani∣mosities have so long har∣bour'd amongst us.

DIV4.P: of the Peace, and other Gentlemen, and Free-Hold∣ers of the County of Somer∣set, do most chearfully lay hold of this Opportunity to renew our Assurance, that we will always stand by, and assist Your Majesty to the utmost of our Power, in the Defence of Your Sa∣cred Person, Title, and Go∣vernment, and in maintain∣ing the Protestant Successi∣on, as well against the Pre∣tender, and all his Adhe∣rents Abroad, as against all Hypocritical Pretenders to Loyalty at Home, and in preserving the Church of England as Establish'd by Law, in their Primitive Pu∣ritp, in Opposition to all Trayterous, Popish, Sediti∣ous, and Republican Prin∣ciples, which strike at the Root of the Monarchy, and all Heretical Tenents, which tend to the utter Ruin, and Subversion of the Establish'd Church.

And We most Humbly beg Leave, to assure Your Majesty, that as we will continue to shew our De∣testation of such Horrid Principles, whether Popish, or Republican, by being in∣cessant in our Endeavours to discourage and suppress them, so we will most con∣stantly choose such Persons to represent us in Parlia∣ment, as love the Monar∣chy,

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
The Address of Your Majesty's Loyal Sub∣jects, the Mayor, &c. of Cliffton Dart∣mouth-Hardness, in the County of Devon.
DIV3.P: WE presume (full of Transports of Joy) to throw our selves at your Royal Feet, heartily to Con∣gratulate the Happy Birth of the Prince, the Greatest Blessing that good Subjects cou'd Desire, or Heaven could Grant. And (as the best Obligation of Loyal

DIV4.P: and are Eminent for their unbiass'd Loyalty, and Affection to Your Majesty's Person, and Government, resolute in maintaining the Just Prerogative of the Crown, and the Protestant Succession, affectionately zealous for the Doctrines and Discipline of our un∣blemish'd Church, and of experienc'd Abilities, and Inclinations to secure the Just Rights, Liberties, and Properties of all Your Ma∣jesty's Subjects, &c.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Humble Address of the Mayor, &c. of Cliffton Dart∣mouth-Hardness, in the County of Devon.
DIV4.P: AS We cannot but with the greatest Joy and Sa∣tisfaction, congratulate Your Majesty upon the good News of Your Majesty's Forces un∣der the Conduct of Your Majesty's Great General the Duke of MARLBOROƲGH, in Conjunction with those of the Allies (which seems

DIV3.P: Hearts) we sincerely offer up our best Prayers and Wishes, that he may enjoy a Long and Happy Life, That your Sacred Majesty, as well for his sake, as for the Invaluable Good and Be∣nefit of these Kingdoms, may live to the utmost Period of Humane Life, to instruct him by your Gracious Exam∣ple in Piety, Prudence, Cou∣rage, and all the Royal Qua∣lifications of a King, of which your Sacred Majesty is the most perfect Pattern; and when you shall change this Crown for an Immortal One, may he then, with these your Dominions, inherit also your Royal, and Princely Virtues.

And we presume, also, at this Time, to repeat our Fixed and Loyal Resolutions of serving your Sacred Ma∣jesty on all Occasions, with our Lives and Fortunes; and we sincerely offer you our Hearty Thanks for your Late Declaration of Liberty of Conscience: And whenever your Majesty shall summon a Parliament, we will choose such Members, as shall en∣tirely, and without Condi∣tions, answer your Royal Ex∣pectation in Repealing the Penal Laws and Test, not thinking it consistent with the Duty of Subjects to make Conditions with their King,

DIV4.P: to presage a Happy and Glorious Campaign) (which God grant) so we think our selves in Duty bound to as∣sure Your Majesty, that as we our selves are, and al∣ways will continue steady, and Loyal to Your Majesty's Person, and Government, both in Church and State, so will we take Care (as we hitherto have done) to send such Representatives to Par∣liament, as shall be Men of known Integrity, and Invio∣lable Loyalty to Your Ma∣jesty, truly zealous for main∣taining the Protestant Reli∣gion, and the Succession in the Illustrious House of Han∣nover, of a firm Constancy, and Zeal to the Principles, and Interest of the Church of England as by Law Estab∣lish'd, and not in the least tainted with those new an∣gled Notions of Resistance, which have been of late so hotly reviv'd amongst us, and which directly tend to the utter Ruin, and Sub∣version of the best Consti∣tution and Establishment. Which, that God may ever preserve, and long continue Your Majesty to be the Support of. &c.

DIV3.P: with so Gracious a King! but as your Majesty's Mercy and Indulgence is free and unli∣mited, so shall our Obedience be. May your Sacred Ma∣jesty live Long and Happily, may all your Enemies, either heartily repent and implore your Mercy, or suffer by your Justice, &c.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
The Staffordshire Ad∣dress.
DIV3.P: WE hope the Lateness of this Address will not be attributed to Want of Loyalty in us, since it comes with the first Oppor∣tunity the Body of the County cou'd be prevail'd on, having hitherto been detain'd from paying its Duty by an Over-Ruling Party among us. We there∣fore, tho' late, yet with u∣nited Affections, come to offer the Tribute of our Acknowledgments to your Sacred Majesty, for your Gracious Declaration, Indul∣gent Distribution of your Dispensing Power, and with Hearts full of Joy congratu∣late

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Staffordshire Ad∣dress.
DIV4.P: SInce your Majesty is pleas'd to allow us in this Manner to approach your Throne, we take this Opportunity of our Pub∣lick Meeting, to follow the seasonable Example of other Counties, with Zeal equal to, (and if possible exceed∣ing) those before us, to express the Part we have in the Common, National Concern for your Sacred Person, Prerogative and Government, Our Holy Church, its Doctrine and Ordinances in the Defence of which, we are willing to make a cheerful Oblation of our selves and Fortunes, a∣gainst

DIV3.P: the FRƲITFƲLNESS of Your Royal Consort, which as it the Hopes and Expec∣tations of all Loyal Souls, so may it frustrate the great End of the Factious, by the Happy Production of a PRINCE of WALES. And when your Majesty, shall in your Princely wisdom, think fit to call a Parliament, it shall be our Study and Care, to promote the Election of such Members, as will, by their Concurrence in Abo∣lishing the Penal Laws, and Test, perfect the great Work of Peace, so graciously and auspiciously undertaken by your Majesty. And that your Reign, &c.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
The Lancashire Ad∣dress.
DIV3.P: NOthing but the Want of a more early Op∣portunity of representing the Body of this County could have with-held your Majesty's most Loyal and Joyful Subjects, from a more

DIV4.P: all Schismatical, Treacherous and inward E∣nemies, as well against all outward and declared ones. And as a farther Instance of our Duty, we in our several Capacities will carefully en∣deavour and suppress all the Prophane, Seditious and Re∣bellious Tenents so openly profess'd, and more impu∣dently and perniciously main∣tain'd and propagated, and will, as we have hitherto done, choose such only to represent us in succeeding Parliaments, as are True, and Approved Sons of the Church, Dutiful and Loy∣al Subjects to the Crown, and Faithful to the Suc∣cession, as by Law Establish'd.
And that Your Majesty, &c.

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Lancashire Ad∣dress.
DIV4.P: WE do most humbly beg Leave to assure your Majesty, that our hear∣ty and sincere Affections to your Royal Person, our Zeal for the Church E∣stablish'd in England, and

DIV3.P: speedy Congratulation of your Majesty and your Roy∣al Consort upon the Birth of the Prince of Wales: Succession in the Right Line has been the Care, and now immediately from your Ma∣jesty, is the Joy not only of us, but of all your. Domi∣nions, the Transports of Foreign Courts upon this Illustrious Birth, is an early Presage, that his Fame shall be more extended, and his Virtues more shining than their Illuminations; may his Heroick Endowments fill all Europe with Terror and Re∣gard, your Majesties with Comfort and Satisfaction, and your Dominion with Peace, Security and Happi∣ness, 'till Time shall be no more, which shall be the faithful Endeavour, &c.

DIV4.P: our firm Resolution to de∣fend both with our Lives and Fortunes against all E∣nemies Foreign and Do∣mestick make us presume to address Your Majesty, in Hopes of your Gracious Protection, and Encourage∣ment to us, to persevere in our True Zeal and Hearty Wishes, that the Enemies to both our Church and State may be disco∣ver'd, and discourag'd from any Wicked Practices and Attempts whatsoever. And we pray God to grant your Majesty a Long, and Pros∣perous Reign over us, to defend You from any Evil Accidents, Plots, and Con∣trivances that may be form'd against Your Sacred Person by dangerous Papists, or treacherous Schismaticks of this Realm, and that the Establish'd Church in this Kingdom may flourish, and the Protestant Succession be preserv'd to future Ages. In Order to which, we will use our utmost Endeavours to send such Representa∣tives to the Ensuing Par∣liament, as will amply testi∣fy the Duty of us Your Majesty's most Loyal Sub∣jects, and Sons of that A∣postolical Church.

DIV3.HEAD: To King JAMES.
The Northumberland Address.
DIV3.P: HAving already with most sincere Devotion paid our Acknowledgments to God Almighty the Father of Mercies, we come now most humble prostrate at your Majesty's Feet, to offer our hearty Congratulations to your Majesty and Royal Consort, for the inestimable Blessing of a Prince of Wales, a Prince giv'n by Divine Providence, to the Prayers of your Kingdoms, to per∣petuate your Majesty's Glo∣ry, and our Pelicity: May he so thrive, (and we doubt it not) under the great Ex∣ample of your Majesty's Pi∣ety and Prudence, that you your self may live to see him consummate in all the true Arts of Government, we far∣ther promise with the best of our Endeavours to send such Members to the next Parliament, as will co-ope∣rate with your Majesty's Gracious Intentions (accord∣ing to your Royal Declara∣tion)

DIV4.HEAD: To Queen ANNE.
The Address from New∣castle upon Tine.
DIV4.P: WE Your Majesty's most Dutiful and Obedient Subjects crave Leave to con∣gratulate your Majesty upon the early and successful Pro∣gress of your Armies, and those of your High Allies, which we believe to be the Continuance of God's Bles∣sing attending your Majesty's exemplary Piety and Good∣ness, as well as the consum∣mate Conduct of your Gene∣rals, and undaunted Courage of your Souldiers, and we shall ever cheerfully contribute to the effectual carrying on this necessary War, 'till the Com∣mon Enemy be disabled to give any farther Disturbance to the Peace of Europe, or to your Majesty's just Right and Title to the Imperial Crown of this Realm.
In your Majesty's Safety our Church as by Law Establish'd, our Laws, Liberties, and every Thing that is dear to us is se∣cure, and we are well assur'd by constant Experience du∣ring

DIV3.P: in repealing the Penal Laws and Test, as Obstacles to your Majesty's Glory and equal Justice, as well to our Ease and Happiness, well knowing that your Majesty will heal us, as a most In∣dulgent and Impartial Fa∣ther doth his many Sons, giving evēry one a share in his Esteem and Affec∣tion, according to their par∣ticular Merits and Quali∣fications.

DIV4.P: the whole Course of your Glorious Reign, as well as by your Royal Word, That no Prince that ever sat on the Throne hath been more really and sincere∣ly kind to the Church, nor ever bad a more true and tender Concern for its Welfare than Your Ma∣jesty.

An Original Power and Right of Resistance in Subjects, are what we never learn'd ei∣ther from our Religion or Laws, and hope never to feel the Effects of them. But we are taught, and fully assur'd, that it's our Duty to be firmly Loyal, and Obedient to your Majesty's Person and Government, to be zealously affected to the Church of England, and the Protestant Succession, as they are Estab∣lish'd by Law against the Pretender, and all Popish, An∣timonarchical, and Republican Opposers whatsoever.
And we do earnestly be∣seech Almighty God, &c.

DIV2.HEAD: The Conclusion.
DIV2.P: NOW, Gentlemen, it has been a New and Approved Custom, and I think, it was begun by this very Doctor Sacheverell, whose Case the Addressers are Espousing, I mean, to prove and disprove from Quotations and Parts of Things, whether Blasphemous, Profane, Atheistical, or otherwise, as appears by his Collections brought before the Lords at his Tryal, and afterwards burnt by the Hangman.

We are, therefore, taking them in their own Way, and in Order to it, you have here repre∣sented to you a Chain of Smoak, a New Feather made of Fine Air, a Web spun of pure Vapour, the Warp is much of it Blasphemy, and the Woof Non∣sence. Wou'd any Man perswade me, the honest People that have talkt these Things to their So∣vereign, were so wicked as to have any Mean∣ing! Is it possible, they cou'd desire that we shou'd suppose they meant any Thing? Above all, Can we think they were such Fools, to ex∣pect the Princes to whom their Addresses were severally directed, cou'd imagine any Meaning in them! I hope, no Body that reads those Sheets can be so uncharitable.

DIV3.HEAD: For Example.
DIV3.P:
When the City of Carlisle in their Second Ad∣dress to King James, talk of being Transported a∣bove Mortals, of God Almighty's PROJECTS: Of King James's Ʋnparallell'd Dangers: Of The Miracle of the Prince of Wales's Birth: Of the Qualities of King James above Constantine: And of Spending
their Lives and Fortunes for the Young Gentleman's Safety:

When the same City in their Address before the Birth they speak of, say, They thank him for His ROYAL ARMY, which really is both the Ho∣nour and Safety of the Nation; that they will not fail to choose such Members, as will certainly concur with His Majesty, &c.

Can any Man be so Weak and Foolish, or in∣deed, so Ʋnkind to the Citizens of Carlisle, as to think they had any Meaning in all this—Have their Actions since giv'n the least Ground of Suspicion that they meant any Thing? Have any One of 'em spent their Lives and Fortunes for the Pretender? Have they not Twice, or Three Times since that, addrest the Princes that keep him out? and, perhaps, with as much Mean∣ing: The Sum of all is, they were as honest, and had as much Meaning as Addressors are expected to have, or as most of them ever have.

Next let us come to the Bath, warm in their Acknowledgments for their Young Prince, as their Hot Springs, which they bousted helpt his Mo∣ther to Conceive; when good Men, in their Ad∣dress to King James, they Congratulate Him for being the Parent of so good a Son, (To be sure much of his Goodness was then known, for he was full 22 Days old.) Then of this Son be∣ing the Reward of Heaven for His Majesty's Decla∣ration for Liberty of Conscience; or in plainer Eng∣lish, Heaven's Reward for the Merit of His Ma∣jesty's Breaking the Laws. Then, that they desire the Young Prince and His Posterity may live to baffle Mortality it self.

Let no Man be so foolish to charge the Ho∣nest Citizens of Bath with meaning what they said in these Things, No No! they were better
Christians, as well as wiser Men, these Things were only Addresses, that is Words of Course with∣out any Signification, and cannot, without Breach of Charity, be taken otherwise.

Cou'd it be possible, the Citizens of Bath cou'd say with any Meaning, We do Promise and Engage upon our Allegiance, that whenever Your Majesty shall think fit to call a Parliament, we will choose none to serve therein, but such as will give us full Assurance, that they will endeavour the Total Abrogation of the Penal Laws and Test.

Just as much Meaning, and just as punctually to be perform'd, are the like Protestations of our present Address from the same City, to which we refer; viz. That Daring to deny the Queen's Hereditary Right is a Damnable Doctrine, and that Such cannot be call'd Her Majesty's Subjects, &c. Whereas Her best Subjects, and also the Laws expresly deny it.

For a little more West-Country Meaning, let us take the Loyal City of Exeter, and here you have them telling their Popish Monarch,—of their Thanking God for the Ʋniversal Blessing of His Reign: Of His most Gracious and Merciful Government: (WESTERN MERCY!) Of His Actions having surpass'd any Thing that History cou'd offord: And to sum up all, That His Decla∣ration of Indulgence (to Popery as well as Dissenters) hath come up to the Agreeableness of Divinity it self, that is, they made Him a God: Then they tell him of His Eternal Honour and Glory, and the Genera∣tion having great Cause to bless God for Him; and the like monstrous Stuff! P. 22.
